title: Decorative initial
content:
Looking to identify the M for a friend.

[link to image.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415144322/http:/m.imgur.com/IeAcYUE)sorry, posting from mobile
author: Jared Benson

comments.content:
It appears to be (very nice) artwork based upon an old typeface digitized by Lime as [Extra Ornamental No. 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415144322/http:/www.dafont.com/extra-ornamental.font). As such, I don't think a font was directly used.

This appears in the Solotype Catalog (metal, wood and photo type) as Tuscan Floral.

Good find Mike. Looks like a 19th century design by Caslon circa 1854 -- as seen in Gray's \_19th Century Ornamented Typefaces\_. Later sold in the U.S. by James Conner's & Sons.  
Don

For anyone wishing to do a high quality recreation of the font I recommend the reproduction in F.W. Lambert's \_Letter Forms (1964)\_ of the full alphabet of Extra Ornamented No.2 as produced by Stevens Shanks circa 1900. Here is the \_M\_

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415144322im_/http:/typophile.com/files/M_ExtraOrnNo2StevensShanks1900ca_6719.jpg)
  
Don

Extra Ornamental No2 by House of Lime

[http://www.dafont.com/extra-ornamental.font?text=M](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415144322/http:/www.dafont.com/extra-ornamental.font?text=M "http://www.dafont.com/extra-ornamental.font?text=M")
